LayerNorm vs RMSNorm: What’s different?

12 Feb 2026

What they normalize?

LayerNorm

For a hidden vector x∈Rdx \in \mathbb{R}^dx∈Rd﻿ (one token, one layer), LN does:

So LN outputs zero-mean, unit-variance (per token, across hidden dims), then applies learnable scale γ\gammaγ﻿ and bias β\betaβ﻿.

RMSNorm(Root Mean Square Norm)

Usually there’s no β\betaβ﻿ (bias) term in RMSNorm (though you can add it).

What it implies in practice

Compute / simplicity

  • RMSNorm is cheaper: no mean, no variance of centered values.
  • Fewer ops and sometimes easier to fuse efficiently.

Behavior

  • LN is invariant to adding a constant shift: xx x﻿→\to→﻿ x+cx + c x+c﻿ won’t change the normalized output (before γ\gammaγ﻿,β\betaβ﻿).
  • RMSNorm is not shift-invariant.

Stability / training

  • In modern Transformers (especially pre-norm), RMSNorm often trains just as well and is common in LLMs (e.g., LLaMA-style).
  • LN gives a bit more “strict” normalization (center + scale), which can sometimes help in settings where shifts matter.

When does RMSNorm help (vs LayerNorm)?

What RMSNorm changes

  • LayerNorm centers + scales:
    • subtract mean, divide by std
  • RMSNorm scales only:
    • divide by RMS magnitude (no mean subtraction)

Where RMSNorm helps most

  1. Efficiency / kernel simplicity
    • Fewer reductions/ops than LN → easier to fuse, slightly faster, slightly less overhead.
    • At LLM scale, tiny savings per layer add up.
  1. Works very well with pre-norm + residual
    • In pre-norm, you already have a strong residual pathway; you mostly want the norm to control scale (keep activations in a good range). RMSNorm does exactly that without forcing zero-mean.
  1. Stable behavior with bf16/fp16 pipelines
    • RMSNorm often behaves nicely in mixed precision because it avoids the mean-subtraction step (one less place for cancellation/rounding sensitivity), though this is not a universal “always better” — it’s more like “rarely worse” in common LLM setups.

When LN might be preferable

  • If your model or data causes large mean shifts that hurt training, LN’s centering can help.
  • If you rely on shift-invariance (LN is invariant to adding a constant bias across features; RMSNorm isn’t).

Practical guidance

  • Deep decoder-only LLM (pre-norm): RMSNorm is a very common “good default”.
  • Encoder / older architectures / some fine-tuning regimes: LayerNorm is still totally fine and sometimes better.
